advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement, office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 64 BITS IN 1983?</strong></font><br><blockquote>After the optimistic 36 Mhz. speed, here is the 64 bits processing power... with 8 bits/Z80 cards. Here also, the 64 bits 'power' is obtained by putting eight 8 bits cards together in the case.<br> Not a very honest way to sell a computer that is no more than a classic S-100 / Z80 based system with some multi-user capabilities.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Imagine a microcomputer with all the design savvy, ruggedness, and sophistication of the best minicomputers.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by dozens of interface, memory and processor option boards. One that can be Interfaced to an indefinite number of peripheral devices including dual floppy discs, CRTs, line printers, cassette recorders, video displays, paper tape readers, teleprinters. plotters, and custom devices.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by extensive software IncludIng Extended BASIC, DISK BASIC, DOS and a complete library of business, developmental, and Industrial programs.<br> ImagIne a microcomputer that will do everything a mini will do, only at a fraction of the cost.<br> You are imagining the Altair 8800b. The Altair 8800b is here today, and it may very welt be the mainframe of the 70's. <br><br> The Altair 8800b is a second generation design of the most popular microcomputer In the field, the Altair 8800. Built around the 8800A microprocessor, the Altair 8800b is an open ended machine that is compatible with all Altair 8800 hardware and software. It can be configured to match most any system need.<br> MITS' plug-In compatible boards for the Altair 8800b now include: 4K static memory. 4K dynamic memory, 16K static memory, multi-port serial interface, multi-port parallel interface, audio cassette record interface, vectored interrupt, real time clock, PROM board, multiplexer, AID convertor, extender card, disc controller and line printer interface.<br> MITS' peripherals for the Altair 8800b include the Altair Floppy Disc, Altair Line Printer, teletypewriters, and the soon-to-be-announced Altair CRT terminal. <br><br> Introductory prices for the Altair 8800b are $840 for a kit with complete assembly instructions, and $1100 for an assembled unit. Complete documentation, membership into the Altair Users Club, subscription to "Computer Notes", access to the Altair Software Library, and a copy of Charles J. Sippi's Microcomputer Dictionary are included.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>

computer.description:
In 1947, Maston Beard and Trevor Pearcey led a research group at the Sydney-based Radiophysics Laboratory of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research [known as CSIRO* today], to design and build the first Australian electronic computer.
The resources they had available included the vacuum tube or "valve" technology and the pulse techniques developed for radar systems during World War II. Their developments paralleled, but were to a considerable extent independent of computer developments in Europe and the USA.
The CSIR Mk1 ran its first test programs in late 1949 and it was the fifth electronic stored program computer ever developed. It embodied many features novel at the time and was able to operate more than 1000 times faster than the best mechanical calculators. The machine was officially opened in 1951 and used to solve problems both for the Radiophysics Laboratory and outside organisations. It was decommissioned in 1955 and shipped to Melbourne.
On 14 June 1956 the Mk1 was recommissioned and renamed CSIRAC and the new Computation Laboratory at the University of Melbourne was officially opened. It was in Melbourne that CSIRAC came into its own as a general computing workhorse - from June 1956 to June 1964 over 700 computing projects were processed.
In November 1964, Dr. Frank Hirst switched CSIRAC off for the last time and donated it to the Museum of Victoria. It is now at the Melbourne Museum, and was modified to blink its lights on and off for the exhibition, although it isn't actually turned on.
Information taken from the detailed page of the University of Melbourne dedicated to the CSIRAC computer.
computer.name: CSIRAC
computer.ram: 768 x 20-bit words stored in mercury delay lines
computer.sound: Built-in speaker able to play primitive music
computer.speed: About 500 instructions per second, later raised to 1000 i/s
